habitat_description:
This species inhabits grassy areas of desert shrubland, chaparral, pinyon/juniper and ponderosa pine woodland of New Mexico, Texas, and northern Mexico.  The little striped whiptail occurs in areas with sandy, silty, or gravelly soil (Stebbins 2003).In New Mexico, it can be found in gentle slopes, including floodplains and prairie dog towns (Degenhardt et al. 1996). Jones and Lovich (2009) report this species to be commonly found in low to mid elevations (900-1600m). In New Mexico, this whiptail can be found up to 2300 meters (San Juan River watershed) (Degenhardt et al. 1996).

Grassy or shrubby desert areas, chaparral, pinon/juniper and into the northwestern part of its range, open ponderosa pine forests. Associated with yuccas, Mormon teas, mesquites, Creosote Bush, and snakeweed (Jones and Lovich 2009).
